hebrew_text: תָּנָא: וְכֵן בְּהַלֵּל, וְכֵן בִּקְרִיאַת שְׁמַע וּבִתְפִלָּה.
human_translation: taught also to hallel , and also to the recitation of Shema , and to prayer,
llm_translation: It was taught: And so too in Hillel, and so too in the recitation of the Shema and in prayer.

hebrew_text: הַלֵּל מְנָלַן? רַבָּה אָמַר, דִּכְתִיב: ״מִמִּזְרַח שֶׁמֶשׁ עַד מְבוֹאוֹ״. רַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר: ״זֶה הַיּוֹם עָשָׂה ה׳״.
human_translation: From where do we hallel Rabba said: As it is written “From the rising of the sun until its setting Rav Yosef said: “This is the day that the Lord has made”
llm_translation: Hillel, from where do we derive his teachings? Rabbah said, as it is written: "From the rising of the sun to its setting." Rav Yosef said: "This refers to the day that the Lord has made."

hebrew_text: רַב אַוְיָא אָמַר: ״יְהִי שֵׁם ה׳ מְבוֹרָךְ״. וְרַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב אַחָא בַּר יַעֲקֹב אָמַר: מֵהָכָא: ״מֵעַתָּה וְעַד עוֹלָם״.
human_translation: Rav Avya said: “Blessed be the name of the Lord” Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said, and some say Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov here, “From now and for evermore”
llm_translation: Rav Avya said: "May the name of Hashem be blessed." And Rav Nachman bar Yitzchak, and it was taught: Rav Acha bar Yaakov said: From here: "From now and forever."

hebrew_text: קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע, דְּתַנְיָא: קְרִיאַת שְׁמַע כִּכְתָבָהּ, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי, וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: בְּכׇל לָשׁוֹן. מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי? אָמַר קְרָא:
human_translation: reciting the Shema As it is taught The recital of the Shema must be as it is written, the statement of Rabbi But the Rabbis say: in any language. What is the reason of Rabbi The verse states:
llm_translation: Reading the Shema, as it was taught: Reading the Shema as it is written, the words of Rabbi, and the sages say: in any language. What is the reason for Rabbi's opinion? The verse says:

hebrew_text: ״וְהָיוּ״, בַּהֲוָיָתָן יְהוּ. וְרַבָּנַן, מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר קְרָא: ״שְׁמַע״, בְּכׇל לָשׁוֹן שֶׁאַתָּה שׁוֹמֵעַ.
human_translation: “And shall be” “shall be” as they are, And the Sages, what is the reason The verse states: “Hear, in any language that you hear,
llm_translation: "And they shall be," in their existence they will be. And the sages, what is the reason? The verse says: "Hear," in every language that you hear.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי נָמֵי, הָא כְּתִיב: ״שְׁמַע״? הַהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ: הַשְׁמַע לְאָזְנֶיךָ מַה שֶּׁאַתָּה מוֹצִיא מִפִּיךָ. וְרַבָּנַן — סָבְרִי כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע וְלֹא הִשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ יָצָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi as well, isn’t it written, “hear”? This is necessary Make heard to your ears what your mouth is saying, And the Sages hold like the one who said one recites the Shema but does not make it audible to his ears, he has fulfilled
llm_translation: Rabbi Namei said: Is it not written: "Hear"? That one wants to say to him: Hear with your ears what you are uttering from your mouth. And the Rabbis hold: Just as one who reads the Shema but does not cause his ear to hear, he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן נָמֵי, הָכְתִיב ״וְהָיוּ״? הַהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ שֶׁלֹּא יִקְרָא לְמַפְרֵעַ. וְרַבִּי, שֶׁלֹּא יִקְרָא לְמַפְרֵעַ מְנָא לֵיהּ? מִ״דְּבָרִים״ ״הַדְּבָרִים״. וְרַבָּנַן — ״דְּבָרִים״ ״הַדְּבָרִים״ לָא מַשְׁמַע לְהוּ.
human_translation: And the Sages as well, isn’t it written, “And shall be”? That is necessary that one must not recite out of order, And from where does Rabbi that one must not recite out of order? Words, “the words,” And the Sages words “the words” is inconsequential according to them.
llm_translation: The sages said, it is written "and they shall be"? That one wants to say that one should not read it as "and they shall be unruly." And Rabbi, how does he derive that one should not read it as "and they shall be unruly"? From "words" "the words." And the sages - "words" "the words" does not imply to them.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא קָסָבַר רַבִּי כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ בְּכׇל לָשׁוֹן נֶאֶמְרָה, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ נֶאֶמְרָה — לְמָה לִי לְמִכְתַּב ״וְהָיוּ״!
human_translation: Shall we say that Rabbi maintains the entire Torah may be recited in any language? As, if it enters your mind may be recited only in the sacred tongue, why do I to write “and shall be”
llm_translation: Let us say, Rabbi holds, the entire Torah was spoken in every language, for if you were to suggest it was spoken in the holy tongue, why would I need it written "and they shall be"!

hebrew_text: אִצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ ״שְׁמַע״ — כְּרַבָּנַן, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״וְהָיוּ״.
human_translation: it is necessary it might have entered your mind “hear” as the Sages, the Merciful One writes “and shall be,”
llm_translation: It is necessary, as your mind requires, "listen" — like the Rabbis, the Merciful One wrote "and they shall be."

hebrew_text: לֵימָא קָסָבְרִי רַבָּנַן כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה בִּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ נֶאֶמְרָה, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ בְּכׇל לָשׁוֹן נֶאֶמְרָה — לְמָה לִי לְמִכְתַּב ״שְׁמַע״!
human_translation: Shall we say that the Sages maintain the entire Torah must be recited in the sacred tongue, As, if it enters your mind may be recited in any language, why do I to write “hear”
llm_translation: Let us say, the sages hold, the entire Torah was spoken in the holy language, for if you were to suggest it was spoken in any language, why do I need the word "Shema" written?

hebrew_text: אִיצְטְרִיךְ, סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא ״וְהָיוּ״ — כְּרַבִּי, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״שְׁמַע״.
human_translation: it was necessary it could enter your mind to say “and shall be” as Rabbi the Merciful One writes “hear”
llm_translation: It is necessary, as your mind has concluded, I say "and they shall be" - like Rabbi, as the Merciful One wrote "Hear."

hebrew_text: תְּפִלָּה מְנָא לַן? דְּתַנְיָא: שִׁמְעוֹן הַפָּקוֹלִי הִסְדִּיר שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה בְּרָכוֹת לִפְנֵי רַבָּן גַּמְלִיאֵל עַל הַסֵּדֶר בְּיַבְנֶה. אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ בְּמַתְנִיתָא תָּנָא: מֵאָה וְעֶשְׂרִים זְקֵנִים, וּבָהֶם כַּמָּה נְבִיאִים, תִּיקְּנוּ שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה בְּרָכוֹת עַל הַסֵּדֶר.
human_translation: prayer From where do we As it is taught Shimon HaPakuli arranged the eighteen blessings before Rabban Gamliel in their order in Yavne, Rabbi Yoḥanan said, and some say that it was taught in a baraita : A hundred and twenty Elders, among them several prophets, established eighteen blessings in their order,
llm_translation: Prayer, from where do we derive it? For it was taught: Shimon HaPakoli arranged eighteen blessings before Rabban Gamliel in Yavneh. Rabbi Yochanan said, and some say it was taught in a baraita: One hundred and twenty elders, among them several prophets, instituted eighteen blessings in order.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאוֹמְרִים אָבוֹת — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הָבוּ לַה׳ בְּנֵי אֵלִים״. וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁאוֹמְרִים גְּבוּרוֹת — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הָבוּ לַה׳ כָּבוֹד וָעוֹז״. וּמִנַּיִן שֶׁאוֹמְרִים קְדוּשּׁוֹת — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הָבוּ לַה׳ כְּבוֹד שְׁמוֹ הִשְׁתַּחֲווּ לַה׳ בְּהַדְרַת קֹדֶשׁ״.
human_translation: The Sages taught From where that one says the Patriarchs, As it is stated: “Ascribe to the Lord, mighty ones” And from where that one says mighty deeds? As it is stated “Ascribe to the Lord glory and strength” And from where that one says holiness? As it is stated “Give to the Lord the glory due to His name; worship the Lord in the beauty of holiness”
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: From where do we derive that we recite the Avot (Patriarchs)? — As it is stated: "Ascribe to the Lord, O sons of mighty ones." And from where do we derive that we recite the Gevurot (mighty acts)? — As it is stated: "Ascribe to the Lord glory and strength." And from where do we derive that we recite the Kedushot (holiness)? — As it is stated: "Ascribe to the Lord the glory due His name; worship the Lord in the splendor of holiness."

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר בִּינָה אַחַר קְדוּשָּׁה — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהִקְדִּישׁוּ אֶת קְדוֹשׁ יַעֲקֹב וְאֶת אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל יַעֲרִיצוּ״, וּסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ: ״וְיָדְעוּ תוֹעֵי רוּחַ בִּינָה״. וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר תְּשׁוּבָה אַחַר בִּינָה — דִּכְתִיב: ״וּלְבָבוֹ יָבִין וָשָׁב וְרָפָא לוֹ״.
human_translation: And why did they see to say understanding after holiness? As it is stated: “They shall sanctify the Holy One of Jacob, and shall revere the God of Israel” “They also that erred in spirit shall come to understanding” And why did they see to say repentance after understanding? As it is written: “And they will understand with their heart, repent, and be healed”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And what did they see fit to say regarding understanding after holiness - as it is stated: "And they shall sanctify the Holy One of Jacob, and they shall revere the God of Israel," and juxtaposed to it: "And those who err in spirit shall come to understanding." And what did they see fit to say regarding repentance after understanding - for it is written: "And his heart shall understand and he shall return and be healed."

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי — לֵימָא רְפוּאָה בָּתְרַהּ דִּתְשׁוּבָה? לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְיָשׁוֹב אֶל ה׳ וִירַחֲמֵהוּ וְאֶל אֱלֹהֵינוּ כִּי יַרְבֶּה לִסְלוֹחַ״.
human_translation: If so, let say the healing should be said after repentance. This cannot enter your mind, as it is written: “And let him return to the Lord, and He will have compassion upon him; and to our God, for He will abundantly pardon”
llm_translation: If so — let us say that healing comes after repentance? It is not according to your opinion, as it is written: "Let him return to the Lord, and He will have compassion on him, and to our God, for He will abundantly pardon."

hebrew_text: וּמַאי חָזֵית דְּסָמְכַתְּ אַהָא? סְמוֹךְ אַהָא! כְּתַב קְרָא אַחֲרִינָא: ״הַסּוֹלֵחַ לְכׇל עֲוֹנֵיכִי הָרוֹפֵא לְכׇל תַּחֲלוּאָיְכִי הַגּוֹאֵל מִשַּׁחַת חַיָּיְכִי״. לְמֵימְרָא דִּגְאוּלָּה וּרְפוּאָה בָּתַר סְלִיחָה הִיא, וְהָכְתִיב: ״וָשָׁב וְרָפָא לוֹ״! הָהוּא לָאו רְפוּאָה דְתַחְלוּאִים הִיא, אֶלָּא רְפוּאָה דִסְלִיחָה הִיא.
human_translation: But what did you see to rely on this Rely on the other Another verse, written: “Who forgives all your iniquities, Who heals all your diseases, Who redeems your life from the pit” Is that to say that redemption and healing forgiveness? But isn’t it written: “Repent, and be healed” That not the healing from illness, but rather the healing of forgiveness,
llm_translation: "What did you see that you relied on Ahah? Rely on Ahah! Another verse is written: 'Who forgives all your iniquities, who heals all your diseases, who redeems your life from the Pit.' It can be said that redemption and healing come after forgiveness, as it is written: 'And he will return and heal him!' That healing is not the healing of physical ailments, but the healing of forgiveness."

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר גְּאוּלָּה בִּשְׁבִיעִית? אָמַר רָבָא: מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁעֲתִידִין לִיגָּאֵל בִּשְׁבִיעִית — לְפִיכָךְ קְבָעוּהָ בִּשְׁבִיעִית. וְהָאָמַר מָר: בְּשִׁשִּׁית קוֹלוֹת, בִּשְׁבִיעִית מִלְחָמוֹת, בְּמוֹצָאֵי שְׁבִיעִית בֶּן דָּוִד בָּא! מִלְחָמָה נָמֵי אַתְחַלְתָּא דִגְאוּלָּה הִיא.
human_translation: And why did they see to say redemption as the seventh Rava said: Since destined to be redeemed in the seventh consequently, they fixed as the seventh But didn’t the Master say In the sixth sounds in the seventh wars; and upon the conclusion of the seventh the son of David, will come? war is also the beginning of the redemption
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And what did they see fit to say 'redemption in the seventh year'? Rava said: Because they will be redeemed in the seventh year - therefore it was established in the seventh year. And Mar said: In the sixth year voices, in the seventh year wars, and at the conclusion of the seventh year, the son of David will come! The war - you have anticipated - is the war of the redemption itself."

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר רְפוּאָה בִּשְׁמִינִית? אָמַר רַבִּי אַחָא: מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁנִּתְּנָה מִילָה בִּשְׁמִינִית שֶׁצְּרִיכָה רְפוּאָה — לְפִיכָךְ קְבָעוּהָ בִּשְׁמִינִית.
human_translation: And why did they see says healing as the eighth Rabbi Aḥa said: Since circumcision was assigned to the eighth requires healing, consequently, they established as the eighth
llm_translation: And what did they see fit to say "healing in the eighth"? Rabbi Akha said: Because a circumcision was performed in the eighth that requires healing - therefore they established it in the eighth.

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר בִּרְכַּת הַשָּׁנִים בִּתְשִׁיעִית? אָמַר רַבִּי אֲלֶכְּסַנְדְּרִי: כְּנֶגֶד מַפְקִיעֵי שְׁעָרִים, דִּכְתִיב: ״שְׁבוֹר זְרוֹעַ רָשָׁע״, וְדָוִד כִּי אַמְרַהּ — בִּתְשִׁיעִית אַמְרַהּ.
human_translation: And why did they see says the blessing of years as the ninth Rabbi Alexandri said: in reference to those who raise the prices as it is written: “Break the arm of the wicked” And when David expressed this he expressed it in the ninth
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And what did they see fit to say regarding the blessing of the years in the ninth year? Rabbi Alexandri said: Like those who break down gates, as it is written: "Break the arm of the wicked," and David said when he said it - he said it in the ninth year.

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר קִיבּוּץ גָּלִיּוֹת לְאַחַר בִּרְכַּת הַשָּׁנִים? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְאַתֶּם הָרֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל עַנְפְּכֶם תִּתֵּנוּ וּפֶרְיְכֶם תִּשְׂאוּ לְעַמִּי יִשְׂרָאֵל כִּי קֵרְבוּ לָבוֹא״. וְכֵיוָן שֶׁנִּתְקַבְּצוּ גָּלִיּוֹת — נַעֲשֶׂה דִּין בָּרְשָׁעִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָשִׁיבָה יָדִי עָלַיִךְ וְאֶצְרוֹף כַּבּוֹר סִיגָיִךְ״, וּכְתִיב: ״וְאָשִׁיבָה שׁוֹפְטַיִךְ כְּבָרִאשׁוֹנָה״.
human_translation: And why did they see says the ingathering of exiles after the blessing of the years? As it is written: “And you, O mountains of Israel, you shall shoot forth your branches, and yield your fruit to My people Israel; for they will soon be coming” And once the exiles have been gathered, judgment will be meted out to the wicked, as it is stated: “And I will turn my hand against you and purge away your dross as with lye” and it is written: “And I will restore your judges as at first”
llm_translation: And what did they see to say "gathering of figs after the blessing of the years"? As it is written: "But you, O mountains of Israel, you shall shoot forth your branches and yield your fruit to My people Israel, for they are about to come." And once the figs were gathered - judgment is executed upon the wicked, as it is said: "And I will lay My hand upon you and will burn your dross as with lye," and it is written: "And I will restore your judges as at the first."

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן שֶׁנַּעֲשָׂה דִּין מִן הָרְשָׁעִים — כָּלוּ הַפּוֹשְׁעִים, וְכוֹלֵל זֵדִים עִמָּהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְשֶׁבֶר פּוֹשְׁעִים וְחַטָּאִים יַחְדָּיו (יִכְלוּ)״.
human_translation: And once judgment is meted out to the wicked, the transgressors, will cease to be. and one includes evildoers with them, as it is stated: “And the destruction of the transgressors and of the sinners shall be together, shall cease to be”
llm_translation: And when judgment is executed from the wicked - the transgressors are consumed, and the wicked are included with them, as it is said: "And the breaking of transgressors and sinners shall be together (they shall be consumed)."

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן שֶׁכָּלוּ הַפּוֹשְׁעִים — מִתְרוֹמֶמֶת קֶרֶן צַדִּיקִים, דִּכְתִיב: ״וְכׇל קַרְנֵי רְשָׁעִים אֲגַדֵּעַ תְּרוֹמַמְנָה קַרְנוֹת צַדִּיק״. וְכוֹלֵל גֵּירֵי הַצֶּדֶק עִם הַצַּדִּיקִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״מִפְּנֵי שֵׂיבָה תָּקוּם וְהָדַרְתָּ פְּנֵי זָקֵן״ — וּסְמִיךְ לֵיהּ: ״וְכִי יָגוּר אִתְּכֶם גֵּר״.
human_translation: And once the heretics cease to be, the horn, of the righteous will be exalted, as it is written: “All the horns of the wicked will I cut off; but the horns of the righteous shall be exalted” And he includes the righteous converts along with the righteous, as it is stated: “You shall rise up before the hoary head, and honor the face of the elder” and adjacent to this “And if a stranger sojourns with you”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And when the wicked perish, there is jubilation of the righteous, as it is written: "And all the horns of the wicked I will cut off, but the horns of the righteous shall be lifted up." And it includes the proselytes with the righteous, as it is said: "You shall rise before the aged and show deference to the old; and if a stranger sojourns with you."

hebrew_text: וְהֵיכָן מִתְרוֹמֶמֶת קַרְנָם — בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שַׁאֲלוּ שְׁלוֹם יְרוּשָׁלִָם יִשְׁלָיוּ אוֹהֲבָיִךְ״.
human_translation: And where will the horns be exalted? In Jerusalem, as it is stated: “Pray for the peace of Jerusalem; they who love you shall prosper”
llm_translation: "And where do their horns emerge? — In Jerusalem, as it is stated: 'Ask for the well-being of Jerusalem; may those who love you be at peace.'"

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן שֶׁנִּבְנֵית יְרוּשָׁלַיִם — בָּא דָּוִד, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר:
human_translation: And once Jerusalem is rebuilt, David, will come, as it is stated:
llm_translation: And when Jerusalem was built - David came, as it is said:

hebrew_text: ״אַחַר יָשׁוּבוּ בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וּבִקְשׁוּ אֶת ה׳ אֱלֹהֵיהֶם וְאֵת דָּוִד מַלְכָּם״. וְכֵיוָן שֶׁבָּא דָּוִד — בָּאתָה תְּפִלָּה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַהֲבִיאוֹתִים אֶל הַר קׇדְשִׁי וְשִׂמַּחְתִּים בְּבֵית תְּפִלָּתִי״.
human_translation: “Afterward the children of Israel shall return, and seek the Lord their God and David their king” And once David comes, prayer will come, as it is stated: “I will bring them to My sacred mountain and make them joyful in My house of prayer”
llm_translation: "אחר ישובו בני ישראל ובקשו את ה׳ אלהיהם ואת דוד מלכם". וכיון שבא דוד — באתה תפלה, שנאמר: "והביאותים אל הר קדשי ושמחתים בבית תפלתי".

hebrew_text: וְכֵיוָן שֶׁבָּאת תְּפִלָּה — בָּאת עֲבוֹדָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״עוֹלוֹתֵיהֶם וְזִבְחֵיהֶם לְרָצוֹן עַל מִזְבְּחִי״. וְכֵיוָן שֶׁבָּאת עֲבוֹדָה — בָּאתָה תּוֹדָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״זוֹבֵחַ תּוֹדָה יְכַבְּדָנְנִי״.
human_translation: And after prayer comes, the service will arrive, as it is stated “Their burnt-offerings and their sacrifices shall be accepted on My altar” And when the service comes, come thanksgiving, as it is stated: “Whoever sacrifices a thanks-offering honors Me”
llm_translation: And when prayer came - came service, as it says: "Their burnt offerings and their sacrifices will be accepted on My altar." And when service came - came thanksgiving, as it says: "He who sacrifices thanksgiving honors Me."

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר בִּרְכַּת כֹּהֲנִים אַחַר הוֹדָאָה? דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּשָּׂא אַהֲרֹן אֶת יָדָיו אֶל הָעָם וַיְבָרְכֵם וַיֵּרֶד מֵעֲשׂוֹת הַחַטָּאת וְהָעוֹלָה וְהַשְּׁלָמִים״.
human_translation: And why did they see says the Priestly Benediction after thanksgiving? As it is written: “And Aaron lifted up his hand toward the people and blessed them, and he came down from sacrificing the sin-offering, and the burnt-offering, and the peace-offerings”
llm_translation: And what did they see to say the Priestly Blessing after the Thanksgiving? As it is written: "And Aaron lifted up his hands towards the people and blessed them, and he descended from offering the sin offering, the burnt offering, and the peace offerings."

hebrew_text: אֵימָא, קוֹדֶם עֲבוֹדָה? לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיֵּרֶד מֵעֲשׂוֹת הַחַטָּאת וְגוֹ׳״. מִי כְּתִיב ״לַעֲשׂוֹת״, ״מֵעֲשׂוֹת״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: say before the service? It should not enter your mind as it is written: “And he came down from sacrificing the sin-offering.” Is it written to sacrifice it is written, “from sacrificing,”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima, kodem avodah? La sakla da'atach, dikhtiv: 'vayered me'asot hachatat ve-go.' Mi k'tiv 'la'asot', 'me'asot' k'tiv." English translation: "Say, before the service? It is not in accordance with your opinion, as it is written: 'and he descended from performing the sin offering, etc.' Who is it written 'to perform', 'from performing' is written."

hebrew_text: וְלֵימְרַהּ אַחַר הָעֲבוֹדָה! לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דִּכְתִיב: ״זוֹבֵחַ תּוֹדָה״.
human_translation: said after the service, It should not enter your mind as it is written: “Whoever sacrifices a thanks-offering
llm_translation: And to say after the service! Not has gone up your mind, as it is written: "One who sacrifices thanksgiving."

hebrew_text: מַאי חָזֵית דְּסָמְכַתְּ אַהַאי, סְמוֹךְ אַהַאי! מִסְתַּבְּרָא עֲבוֹדָה וְהוֹדָאָה חֲדָא מִילְּתָא הִיא.
human_translation: What did you see to rely on this Rely on the other It stands to reason service and thanksgiving, are one matter.
llm_translation: "What do you see that you rely on this? Rely on this! It makes sense that service and acknowledgment are one matter."

hebrew_text: וּמָה רָאוּ לוֹמַר ״שִׂים שָׁלוֹם״ אַחַר בִּרְכַּת כֹּהֲנִים? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְשָׂמוּ אֶת שְׁמִי עַל בְּנֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל וַאֲנִי אֲבָרְכֵם״, בְּרָכָה דְּהַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא שָׁלוֹם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״ה׳ יְבָרֵךְ אֶת עַמּוֹ בַשָּׁלוֹם״.
human_translation: And why did they see says Grant peace, after the Priestly Benediction? As it is written “And they shall put My name upon the children of Israel, and I will bless them” the blessing of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is peace, as it is stated: “The Lord blesses His people with peace”
llm_translation: And what did they see to say "set peace" after the blessing of the priests? As it is written: "And they shall place My name upon the children of Israel, and I will bless them," a blessing from the Holy One, blessed be He, of peace, as it is said: "The Lord will bless His people with peace."

hebrew_text: וְכִי מֵאַחַר דְּמֵאָה וְעֶשְׂרִים זְקֵנִים וּמֵהֶם כַּמָּה נְבִיאִים תִּקְּנוּ תְּפִלָּה עַל הַסֵּדֶר, שִׁמְעוֹן הַפָּקוֹלִי מַאי הִסְדִּיר? שְׁכָחוּם, וְחָזַר וְסִדְּרוֹם.
human_translation: Now, since a hundred and twenty Elders, including many prophets, established the prayer in its order, what Shimon HaPakuli arranged forgot them, and arranged them again.
llm_translation: And when after one hundred and twenty elders, and among them several prophets, established the prayer in order, what did Shimon the Pakoli arrange? He forgot them, and then he went back and arranged them.

hebrew_text: מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ, אָסוּר לְסַפֵּר בְּשִׁבְחוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא. דְּאָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״מִי יְמַלֵּל גְּבוּרוֹת ה׳ יַשְׁמִיעַ כׇּל תְּהִלָּתוֹ״, לְמִי נָאֶה לְמַלֵּל גְּבוּרוֹת ה׳ לְמִי שֶׁיָּכוֹל לְהַשְׁמִיעַ כׇּל תְּהִלָּתוֹ.
human_translation: beyond this it is prohibited to declare the praises of the Holy One, Blessed be He, Rabbi Elazar said: What is which is written: “Who can utter the mighty acts of the Lord? Who can declare all His praise?” For whom is it fitting to utter the mighty acts of the Lord? for one who can declare all His praise.
llm_translation: From here and onwards, it is forbidden to recount the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He. As Rabbi Elazar said, what is the meaning of what is written: "Who can express the mighty acts of the Lord, or make all His praise heard?" To whom is it fitting to express the mighty acts of the Lord? To one who can make all His praise heard.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הַמְסַפֵּר בְּשִׁבְחוֹ שֶׁל הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא יוֹתֵר מִדַּאי — נֶעֱקָר מִן הָעוֹלָם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הַיְסוּפַּר לוֹ כִּי אֲדַבֵּר אִם אָמַר אִישׁ כִּי יְבֻלָּע״.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: one who excessively declares the praises of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is uprooted from the world, As it is stated: “Shall it be told to Him when I speak? If a man says he would be swallowed up”
llm_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: One who recounts the praise of the Holy One, blessed be He, more than is necessary—has removed himself from the world, as it is stated: "Should it be told to Him that I would speak? If a man says that he would be swallowed up."

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אִישׁ כְּפַר גִּבּוֹרַיָּא, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ אִישׁ כְּפַר גִּבּוֹר חַיִל: מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״לְךָ דוּמִיָּה תְהִלָּה״? סַמָּא דְּכוֹלָּה — מַשְׁתּוּקָא. כִּי אֲתָא רַב דִּימִי, אֲמַר: אָמְרִי בְּמַעְרְבָא: מִלָּה — בְּסֶלַע, מַשְׁתּוּקָא — בִּתְרֵין.
human_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, a man of Kefar Gibboraya, and some say a man of Kefar Gibbor Ĥayil, taught: What is which is written: “For You silence is praise” The remedy of all is silence, When Rav Dimi came he said: In the West, they say a word is sela , silence is two.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yehuda, a man of Kfar Gibborayya, expounded and they said to him, a man of Kfar Gibbor Chayil: What is the meaning of what is written: "Yours is the silence that is praise"? The entire matter is silent. When Rav Dimi came, he said: They say in the West: A word in the rock, silent in two.

hebrew_text: קְרָאָהּ עַל פֶּה לֹא יָצָא וְכוּ׳. מְנָלַן? אָמַר רָבָא: אָתְיָא זְכִירָה זְכִירָה, כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וְהַיָּמִים הָאֵלֶּה נִזְכָּרִים״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״כְּתֹב זֹאת זִכָּרוֹן בַּסֵּפֶר״. מָה לְהַלָּן — בְּסֵפֶר, אַף כָּאן — בְּסֵפֶר.
human_translation: If one read by heart he has not fulfilled From where do we Rava said: derived remembrance remembrance. It is written here, “That these days should be remembered” and it is written elsewhere: “And the Lord said to Moses: Write this for a memorial in the book, Just as there, in a book, so too here, in a book.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If one recited it orally, he has not fulfilled his obligation, etc. Whence do we know this? Rava said: Scripture mentions it twice. Here it is written: "And these days are remembered," and there it is written: "Write this as a memorial in the book." Just as there, it is in a book, so too here, it is in a book.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּהַאי זְכִירָה קְרִיאָה הִיא, דִּלְמָא עִיּוּן בְּעָלְמָא! לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ (דִּכְתִיב): ״זָכוֹר״ — יָכוֹל בַּלֵּב? כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״לֹא תִּשְׁכָּח״, הֲרֵי שִׁכְחַת הַלֵּב אָמוּר, הָא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים ״זָכוֹר״ — בַּפֶּה.
human_translation: But from where that this remembrance reading Perhaps merely looking into It should not enter your mind “Remember might in his heart. when it says “You shall not forget” it is referring to forgetting from the heart. How, do I uphold “remember”? with the mouth.
llm_translation: And from what is this mention a reading? Perhaps it is just a general principle! It is not as you think (as it is written): "Remember" - could it be in the heart? When it says "Do not forget," it means forgetting of the heart is spoken of. So how do I fulfill "Remember"? - with the mouth.

hebrew_text: קְרָאָהּ תַּרְגּוּם לֹא יָצָא וְכוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דִּכְתִיבָה מִקְרָא וְקָרֵי לַהּ תַּרְגּוּם, הַיְינוּ עַל פֶּה! לָא צְרִיכָא, דִּכְתִיבָה תַּרְגּוּם וְקָרֵי לַהּ תַּרְגּוּם.
human_translation: If one read in translation he has not fulfilled What are the circumstances If we say that was written in biblical text, and he read it in translation, this is by heart, No, necessary was written in translation, and he read it in translation.
llm_translation: The translation of it, has not fulfilled and so forth. How so? If you say that since it is written in Scripture, one should read it in translation, that is obvious! It is unnecessary, for Scripture is translated and one should read it in translation.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל קוֹרִין אוֹתָהּ לַלּוֹעֲזוֹת בְּלַעַז וְכוּ׳. וְהָא אָמְרַתְּ: קְרָאָהּ בְּכׇל לָשׁוֹן — לֹא יָצָא! רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: בְּלַעַז יְווֹנִי.
human_translation: However, for those who speak a foreign language, one may read in foreign language. But didn’t you say If he read it in any language he has not fulfilled Rav and Shmuel, who both say: the Greek foreign language,
llm_translation: But read it in foreign languages in a foreign language, etc. But didn't you say: If one reads it in any language - he has not fulfilled his obligation! Rav and Shmuel both say: in Greek.

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דִּכְתִיבָה אַשּׁוּרִית וְקָרֵי לַהּ יְווֹנִית, הַיְינוּ עַל פֶּה! אָמַר רַבִּי אַחָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: שֶׁכְּתוּבָה בְּלַעַז יְווֹנִית.
human_translation: What are the circumstances If we say that was written in Ashurit , and he read it in Greek, this is by heart, Rabbi Aḥa said Rabbi Elazar said: was written in the Greek foreign language
llm_translation: "How are the prices determined? Perhaps it is because it is written in Assyrian and read in Greek, that is, by word of mouth! Rabbi Ahah said in the name of Rabbi Elazar: When it is written in the Torah, it is in Greek."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי אַחָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: מִנַּיִן שֶׁקְּרָאוֹ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְיַעֲקֹב ״אֵל״, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיִּקְרָא לוֹ אֵל אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״. דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ לְמִזְבֵּחַ קְרָא לֵיהּ יַעֲקֹב ״אֵל״ — ״וַיִּקְרָא לוֹ יַעֲקֹב״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ! אֶלָּא ״וַיִּקְרָא לוֹ״, לְיַעֲקֹב, ״אֵל״. וּמִי קְרָאוֹ ״אֵל״ — ״אֱלֹהֵי יִשְׂרָאֵל״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Aḥa said Rabbi Elazar said: From where that the Holy One, Blessed be He, called Jacob El, As it is stated: and he called it El, God of Israel” as if it enters your mind Jacob called the altar El, it should have And Jacob called it But He called Jacob El; and who called him El? The God of Israel.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Ahah said in the name of Rabbi Elazar: From where do we derive that the Holy One, blessed be He, called to Jacob "God," as it is stated: "And God called to him, the God of Israel." For if you were to suggest that at the altar He called him "God," then why does it say "And Jacob called to him," what does it need it for? Rather, "And He called to him," to Jacob, "God." And who called him "God" - "the God of Israel."

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: קְרָאָהּ גִּיפְּטִית, עִבְרִית, עֵילָמִית, מָדִית, יְווֹנִית — לֹא יָצָא!
human_translation: raises an objection If one read in Coptic [ Giptit ], Ivrit , Elamite, Median, or Greek, he has not fulfilled
llm_translation: Challenger: Its reading is Gifftit, Ivrit, Eilamit, Madit, Yevonit - he has not fulfilled his obligation!

hebrew_text: הָא לָא דָּמְיָא אֶלָּא לְהָא: גִּיפְּטִית לְגִיפְּטִים, עִבְרִית לְעִבְרִים, עֵילָמִית לְעֵילָמִים, יְווֹנִית לִיווֹנִים — יָצָא.
human_translation: is comparable only to that in Coptic to Copts, Ivrit to Ivrim , in Elamite to Elamites, or in Greek to Greeks, he has fulfilled
llm_translation: Here is the translation of the Talmudic text you provided: Talmudic text: This applies only to this: Gifftit to Gifftim, Ivrit to Ivrim, Eilamit to Eilamim, Yevanit to Yevonim - he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל אַמַּאי מוֹקְמִי לַהּ לְמַתְנִיתִין בְּלַעַז יְווֹנִית? לוֹקְמוּהָ בְּכֹל לַעַז! [אֶלָּא, מַתְנִיתִין כְּבָרַיְיתָא.] וְכִי אִיתְּמַר דְּרַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל, בְּעָלְמָא אִיתְּמַר. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל דְּאָמְרִי תַּרְוַיְיהוּ: לַעַז יְווֹנִי לַכֹּל כָּשֵׁר.
human_translation: if so, why did Rav and Shmuel establish the mishna as to Greek? Let them interpret it to any foreign language Rather, the mishna like the baraita , and that which was stated Rav and Shmuel was said general Rav and Shmuel both say: The Greek language is acceptable for everyone,
llm_translation: So, why did Rav and Shmuel establish the Mishnah in Greek? They could have established it in any language! Rather, the Mishnah is in accordance with the tradition. And if it is said that Rav and Shmuel, it is said in general. Rav and Shmuel both said: Greek is valid for everyone.

hebrew_text: וְהָא קָתָנֵי: יְווֹנִית לִיווֹנִים [לִיווֹנִים] — אִין, לְכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא — לָא! אִינְהוּ דַּאֲמוּר כְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל. דִּתְנַן, רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: אַף סְפָרִים לֹא הִתִּירוּ שֶׁיִּכָּתְבוּ אֶלָּא יְווֹנִית.
human_translation: But doesn’t teach Greek to Greeks yes, for everyone no, agree with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. As we learned Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even books did not permit them to be written other than Greek,
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: But isn't it taught in a Baraita: "Yevanit li'vonim li'vonim" - it is not for everyone in the world? No! They are the ones who said like Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. As we learned in a Mishnah: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: They did not permit even books to be written except in Greek.

hebrew_text: וְלֵימְרוּ: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל? אִי אָמְרִי הֲלָכָה כְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא הָנֵי מִילֵּי שְׁאָר סְפָרִים, אֲבָל מְגִילָּה דִּכְתִיב בַּהּ ״כִּכְתָבָם״ — אֵימָא לָא. קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן.
human_translation: let them state The halakha is in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. Had they said that the halakha is in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, I would have said this applies to the other books but the Megilla, of which it is written: “According to their writing,” I would say not teach us
llm_translation: And they say: Is the halakha according to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? If they say the halakha is according to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, I would have thought that applies to other books, but for the Megillah, since it is written in it "as they wrote," I would say no. This is what we have heard.

hebrew_text: וְהַלּוֹעֵז שֶׁשָּׁמַע אַשּׁוּרִית יָצָא וְכוּ׳. וְהָא לָא יָדַע מַאי קָאָמְרִי? מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַנָּשִׁים וְעַמֵּי הָאָרֶץ.
human_translation: And one who speaks a foreign language who heard in Ashurit , has fulfilled But isn’t he does not understand what they are saying? It is just as it is women and uneducated people;
llm_translation: The foreigner who heard Assyrian went out, etc. But he did not know what they were saying? Because he was among people and the nations of the land.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָבִינָא: אַטּוּ אֲנַן ״הָאֲחַשְׁתְּרָנִים בְּנֵי הָרַמָּכִים״, מִי יָדְעִינַן? אֶלָּא מִצְוַת קְרִיאָה וּפַרְסוֹמֵי נִיסָּא, הָכָא נָמֵי — מִצְוַת קְרִיאָה וּפַרְסוֹמֵי נִיסָּא.
human_translation: Ravina strongly objects to Is that to say we, know ha’aḥashteranim benei haramakhim But mitzva of reading and publicizing the miracle Here too, mitzva of reading and publicizing the miracle,
llm_translation: Rabina objects to her: Do we know that "the Achashdarpanim are the sons of the Ramakim"? Rather, it is a commandment of reading and publicizing the miracle. Here too, it is a commandment of reading and publicizing the miracle.

hebrew_text: קְרָאָהּ סֵירוּגִין יָצָא וְכוּ׳. לָא הֲווֹ יָדְעִי רַבָּנַן מַאי ״סֵירוּגִין״, שַׁמְעוּהָ לְאַמְּתָא דְבֵי רַבִּי דְּקָאָמְרָה לְהוּ לְרַבָּנַן דַּהֲווֹ עָיְילִי פִּסְקֵי פִּסְקֵי לְבֵי רַבִּי: עַד מָתַי אַתֶּם נִכְנָסִין סֵירוּגִין סֵירוּגִין?
human_translation: If one reads at intervals seirugin he has fulfilled the Sages did not know what is seirugin . they heard the maidservant in Rabbi house saying to the Sages who were entering the house intermittently How long are you going to enter seirugin seirugin ?
llm_translation: The potter's vessel went out, etc. The Rabbis did not know what "potter's vessel" meant. They heard the truth from the house of Rabbi, for she said to the Rabbis who were going in pairs to the house of Rabbi: Until when will you enter, potter's vessel, potter's vessel?

hebrew_text: לָא הֲווֹ יָדְעִי רַבָּנַן מַאי ״חֲלוֹגְלוֹגוֹת״. שַׁמְעוּהָ לְאַמְּתָא דְבֵי רַבִּי דַּאֲמַרָה לֵיהּ לְהָהוּא גַּבְרָא דַּהֲוָה קָא מְבַדַּר פַּרְפְּחִינֵי: עַד מָתַי אַתָּה מְפַזֵּר חֲלוֹגְלוֹגְךָ?
human_translation: the Sages did not know what is ḥalogelogot , they heard the maidservant in Rabbi house saying to a certain man who was scattering purslane: How long will you go on scattering your ḥalogelogot ?
llm_translation: The sages did not know what "chaluglugot" are. They heard the truth from the house of Rabbi, for she said to that man who was sifting ashes: "How long will you scatter your chaluglugot?"

hebrew_text: לָא הֲווֹ יָדְעִי רַבָּנַן מַאי ״סַלְסְלֶהָ וּתְרוֹמְמֶךָּ״. שַׁמְעוּהָ לְאַמְּתָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי דַּהֲווֹת אָמְרָה לְהָהוּא גַּבְרָא דַּהֲוָה מְהַפֵּךְ בְּמַזְיֵיהּ, אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: עַד מָתַי אַתָּה מְסַלְסֵל בִּשְׂעָרְךָ?
human_translation: the Sages did not know what is wisdom…salseleha and it will exalt you” they heard the maidservant in Rabbi house talking to a certain man who was twirling his hair, saying to him: How long will you go on twirling mesalsel your hair?
llm_translation: The sages did not know what "salsleha utrommekha" means. They heard the truth from the house of Rabbi, for she used to say to that man who was combing his hair, "Until when will you keep combing your hair?"

hebrew_text: לָא הֲווֹ יָדְעִי רַבָּנַן מַאי: ״הַשְׁלֵךְ עַל ה׳ יְהָבְךָ״. אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה: זִימְנָא חֲדָא הֲוָה אָזֵילְנָא בַּהֲדֵי הָהוּא טַיָּיעָא, וְקָא דָרֵינָא טוּנָא וַאֲמַר לִי: שְׁקוֹל יַהְבָּיךְ וּשְׁדִי אַגַּמְלַאי.
human_translation: The Sages did not know what is “Cast upon the Lord your yehav ” Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: One time I was traveling with a certain Arab Tayya’a and I was carrying a load, and he said to me: Take your yehav and throw it on my camel,
llm_translation: The Sages did not know what is meant by: "Cast upon the Lord your burden." Rabbah bar bar Ḥannah said: One time I was walking on the way with that Arab merchant, and he was carrying a load and said to me: "Take your load and place it on my camel."

hebrew_text: לָא הֲווֹ יָדְעִי רַבָּנַן מַאי ״וְטֵאטֵאתִיהָ בְּמַטְאֲטֵא הַשְׁמֵד״. שַׁמְעוּהָ לְאַמְּתָא דְּבֵי רַבִּי דַּהֲווֹת אָמְרָה לַחֲבֶרְתָּהּ: שְׁקוּלִי טָאטִיתָא וְטַאטִי בֵּיתָא.
human_translation: the Sages did not know what is “And I will tatei it with the matatei of destruction” they heard the maidservant in Rabbi house saying to her friend: Take a tateita and tati the house,
llm_translation: The sages did not know what "and I adorned her with destruction" means. They heard the truth from the house of Rabbi, for she used to say to her friend: "Take your adornments and adorn your house."

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: קְרָאָהּ סֵירוּגִין — יָצָא,
human_translation: the Sages taught If one reads the Megilla at intervals, he has fulfilled
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "If its caul is woven - it is valid."

hebrew_text: סֵירוּסִין — לֹא יָצָא. רַבִּי מוּנָא אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: אַף בְּסֵירוּגִין, אִם שָׁהָה כְּדֵי לִגְמוֹר אֶת כּוּלָּהּ — חוֹזֵר לָרֹאשׁ. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה.
human_translation: out of order, he has not fulfilled Rabbi Mona said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda: Even at intervals, if he pauses enough to finish the whole he must go back to the beginning Rav Yosef said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Mona, stated in the name of Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: "Sirusin - did not fulfill his obligation. Rabbi Muna says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda: Even with serugin, if he remained to complete it all - he returns to the beginning. Rav Yosef said: The halakha is according to Rabbi Muna who said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי לְרַב יוֹסֵף: כְּדֵי לִגְמוֹר אֶת כּוּלָּהּ — מֵהֵיכָא דְּקָאֵי לְסֵיפָא, אוֹ דִלְמָא: מֵרֵישָׁא לְסֵיפָא? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מֵרֵישָׁא לְסֵיפָא, דְּאִם כֵּן, נָתַתָּ דְּבָרֶיךָ לְשִׁיעוּרִין.
human_translation: Abaye said to Rav Yosef: enough to finish the whole from where he is until the end? Or perhaps from the beginning until the end. He said to him: from the beginning until the end, if so you would be subjecting your statement to the circumstances
llm_translation: He said to him Abaye to Rav Yosef: in order to complete it all - from where is he standing to the end, or perhaps: from the beginning to the end? He said to him: from the beginning to the end, for if so, you have given your words to the measurers.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַב: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא. בְּסוּרָא מַתְנוּ הָכִי. בְּפוּמְבְּדִיתָא מַתְנוּ הָכִי: אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא אָמַר רַב: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא. וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא. רַב בִּיבִי מַתְנִי אִיפְּכָא, רַב אָמַר: אֵין הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא, וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי מוּנָא.
human_translation: Rabbi Abba said Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said: Rav said the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Mona, but Shmuel said the halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Mona. This is how they taught in Sura. in Pumbedita they taught like this: Rav Kahana said Rav said the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Mona, but Shmuel said the halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Mona. Rav Beivai taught the opposite: Rav said the halakha is not in accordance with Rabbi Mona, but Shmuel said the halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Mona.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Abba said Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said Rav: The halacha follows Rabbi Muna. And Shmuel said: The halacha does not follow Rabbi Muna. In Sura they taught thus. In Pumbedita they taught thus: Rav Kahana said Rav: The halacha follows Rabbi Muna. And Shmuel said: The halacha does not follow Rabbi Muna. Rav Beivi taught the opposite, Rav said: The halacha does not follow Rabbi Muna, and Shmuel said: The halacha follows Rabbi Muna.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: נְקוֹט דְּרַב בִּיבִי בִּידָךְ, דִּשְׁמוּאֵל הוּא דְּחָיֵישׁ לִיחִידָאָה. דִּתְנַן: שׁוֹמֶרֶת יָבָם שֶׁקִּידֵּשׁ אָחִיו אֶת אֲחוֹתָהּ, מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתִירָה אָמְרוּ, אוֹמְרִים לוֹ: הַמְתֵּן עַד שֶׁיַּעֲשֶׂה אָחִיךָ הַגָּדוֹל מַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: Rav Yosef said: Grasp Rav Beivai in your hand, Shmuel takes into consideration individual As we learned a woman waiting for her brother-in-law and brothers betrothed sister, they said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira: We say to Wait until your older brother acts,
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: Take the case of Rav Bibi into your hand, for Shmuel is the one who is concerned for the individual. As we learned in a Mishnah: A yevamah who was betrothed by her brother-in-law to his sister, due to the ruling of Rabbi Yehudah ben Beteira they said to him: Wait until your older brother performs the act.

hebrew_text: אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה בֶּן בְּתִירָה.
human_translation: Shmuel said: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.
llm_translation: Said Samuel: The halakha is in accordance with Rabbi Yehudah ben Beteira.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הִשְׁמִיט בָּהּ סוֹפֵר אוֹתִיּוֹת אוֹ פְּסוּקִין וּקְרָאָן הַקּוֹרֵא כִּמְתוּרְגְּמָן הַמְתַרְגֵּם — יָצָא.
human_translation: The Sages taught If the scribe omitted letters or verses and the reader read as a translator when translating, he has fulfilled
llm_translation: The Sages taught: If one omitted letters, words, or verses in it, and the reader reads it like the translator who translates, he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: הָיוּ בָּהּ אוֹתִיּוֹת מְטוּשְׁטָשׁוֹת אוֹ מְקוֹרָעוֹת, אִם רִשּׁוּמָן נִיכָּר — כְּשֵׁרָה, וְאִם לָאו — פְּסוּלָה! לָא קַשְׁיָא: הָא בְּכוּלַּהּ, הָא בְּמִקְצָתַהּ.
human_translation: raises an objection If contains letters that are blurred or torn, If their imprint is visible, is fit but if not, it is unfit. This not difficult. This the whole of this in part of it.
llm_translation: Challenger: If there were letters in it that were smudged or torn, if the signature is recognizable - it is valid, and if not - it is invalid! There is no difficulty: here we are talking about the entire document, and here we are talking about part of it.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: הִשְׁמִיט בָּהּ הַקּוֹרֵא פָּסוּק אֶחָד, לֹא יֹאמַר: אֶקְרָא אֶת כּוּלָּהּ וְאַחַר כָּךְ אֶקְרָא אוֹתוֹ פָּסוּק, אֶלָּא קוֹרֵא מֵאוֹתוֹ פָּסוּק וְאֵילָךְ. נִכְנַס לְבֵית הַכְּנֶסֶת וּמָצָא צִבּוּר שֶׁקָּרְאוּ חֶצְיָהּ, לֹא יֹאמַר: אֶקְרָא חֶצְיָהּ עִם הַצִּבּוּר וְאַחַר כָּךְ אֶקְרָא חֶצְיָהּ, אֶלָּא קוֹרֵא אוֹתָהּ מִתְּחִילָּתָהּ וְעַד סוֹפָהּ.
human_translation: The Sages taught If the reader omitted one verse, he may not say: I will read the whole of and afterward I will read that verse Rather, he must read from that verse if one enters a synagogue and encounters a congregation that has read half he may not say: I will read half of the congregation, afterward I will read half. Rather, he must read it from the beginning until the end.
llm_translation: The Rabbis taught: If one omitted a verse while reading, he should not say, "I will read the entire passage and then go back and read that verse," rather he should read from that verse onwards. If one entered the synagogue and found the congregation halfway through the reading, he should not say, "I will read the second half with the congregation and then go back and read the first half," rather he should read it from the beginning to the end.

hebrew_text: מִתְנַמְנֵם יָצָא וְכוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָּמֵי מִתְנַמְנֵם? אָמַר רַב אָשֵׁי: נִים וְלָא נִים, תִּיר וְלָא תִּיר, דְּקָרוּ לֵיהּ וְעָנֵי וְלָא יָדַע לְאַהְדּוֹרֵי סְבָרָא, וְכִי מַדְכְּרוּ לֵיהּ מִידְּכַר.
human_translation: while he is dozing off, he has fulfilled his What are the circumstances of dozing off? Rav Ashi said: asleep yet not asleep, awake yet not awake. If someone calls him he answers. And he is he does not know to provide reasoning, but when people remind him he remembers
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Mitnammem yatza v'chul. Heichi dami mitnammem? Amar Rav Ashe: Nim v'lo nim, tir v'lo tir, dekaru lei v'anei v'lo yada le'ahdorei sevara, v'chi madkru lei midkar." English translation: "If one dozes off, he has fulfilled his obligation, etc. What is the case of 'dozing off'? Rav Ashe said: Whether he is dozing or not, whether he is awake or not, if they called to him and he answered but did not know how to respond to logical arguments, and when they reminded him, he remembered."

hebrew_text: הָיָה כּוֹתְבָהּ דּוֹרְשָׁהּ וּמַגִּיהָהּ אִם כִּוֵּון לִבּוֹ יָצָא וְכוּ׳. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִי דְּקָא מְסַדַּר פְּסוּקָא פְּסוּקָא וְכָתֵב לַהּ, כִּי כִּוֵּון לִבּוֹ מַאי הָוֵי? עַל פֶּה הוּא! אֶלָּא דְּכָתֵב פְּסוּקָא פְּסוּקָא וְקָרֵי לֵיהּ,
human_translation: If one was writing or expounding upon it, or correcting if he had intent he has fulfilled What are the circumstances If he was articulating each verse writing it down, what of it he intended by heart? Rather, he wrote each verse and read it out.
llm_translation: He would write it, expound it, and read it aloud. If his heart was intent, he fulfilled his obligation. How so? If he was arranging verse by verse and writing it, for if his heart was intent, what is the ruling? It is considered as if he said it orally! Rather, he writes verse by verse and reads it aloud.

hebrew_text: וּמִי יָצָא? וְהָאָמַר רַבִּי חֶלְבּוֹ אָמַר רַב חָמָא בַּר גּוּרְיָא אָמַר רַב: הֲלָכָה כְּדִבְרֵי הָאוֹמֵר כּוּלָּהּ. וַאֲפִילּוּ לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״מֵאִישׁ יְהוּדִי״ — צְרִיכָה שֶׁתְּהֵא כְּתוּבָה כּוּלָּהּ!
human_translation: But does one fulfill Didn’t Rabbi Ḥelbo say Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said Rav said: The halakha is in accordance with the statement of the one who says in its entirety And even according to the one who said “There was a certain Jew” must be written in its entirety.
llm_translation: "And who went out? And Rabbi Helbo said in the name of Rav Ḥama son of Guria said Rav: The halakha is in accordance with the words of the one who says it in its entirety. And even according to the one who says 'from a Jewish man' — it must be written in its entirety!"

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: דְּמַנְּחָה מְגִילָּה קַמֵּיהּ וְקָרֵי (לַהּ) מִינַּהּ פְּסוּקָא פְּסוּקָא וְכָתַב לָהּ. לֵימָא מְסַיַּיע לֵיהּ לְרַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה, דְּאָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אָסוּר לִכְתּוֹב אוֹת אַחַת שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב. דִּלְמָא דְּאִתְרְמִי לֵיהּ אִתְרְמוֹיֵי.
human_translation: Rather, which a Megilla is lying before him and he was reading from verse by verse and writing in Let us say that supports Rabba bar bar Ḥana, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is prohibited to write a single letter not from a written text. as perhaps where this is what happened to be
llm_translation: Rather, regarding a Mincha offering, he stands before her and reads from her portion verse by verse and writes for her. Let us say that Rabba bar bar Ḥana assists him, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: It is forbidden to write even one letter not from the Scripture. Perhaps he will be confused.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אָסוּר לִכְתּוֹב אוֹת אַחַת שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב. מֵיתִיבִי, אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּרַבִּי מֵאִיר שֶׁהָלַךְ לְעַבֵּר שָׁנָה בְּעַסְיָא, וְלֹא הָיָה שָׁם מְגִילָּה וּכְתָבָהּ מִלִּבּוֹ — וּקְרָאָהּ!
human_translation: the itself, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is prohibited to write a single letter not from a written text. raises an objection Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: an incident involving Rabbi Meir, who went to intercalate the year in Asia And there was no there so he wrote by heart and read it.
llm_translation: The body, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: It is forbidden to write even one letter not from the Scripture. The Gemara raises an objection: Rabbi Shim'on ben El'azar said: There was an incident involving Rabbi Meir who went to spend a year in Asya, and there was no Megillah there, so he wrote it from memory — and read it!

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ: שָׁאנֵי רַבִּי מֵאִיר דְּמִיקַּיַּים בֵּיהּ ״וְעַפְעַפֶּיךָ יַיְשִׁירוּ נֶגְדְּךָ״. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא לְרַבִּי יִרְמְיָה מִדִּפְתִּי: מַאי ״וְעַפְעַפֶּיךָ יַיְשִׁירוּ נֶגְדְּךָ״? אָמַר לוֹ: אֵלּוּ דִּבְרֵי תוֹרָה, דִּכְתִיב בְּהוּ: ״הֲתָעִיף עֵינֶיךָ בּוֹ וְאֵינֶנּוּ״, וַאֲפִילּוּ הָכִי מְיוּשָּׁרִין הֵן אֵצֶל רַבִּי מֵאִיר.
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said: Rabbi Meir is different, as in him is fulfilled “And let your eyelids look straight before you” Rami bar Ḥama said to Rabbi Yirmeya of Difti: What is “and let your eyelids afapekha ],” “look straight yaishiru before you”? He said to him: This is referring to the words of the Torah, and with regard to which it is written: “Will you glance upon it fleetingly hata’if ], with your eyes? It is already gone” but nevertheless they remain exact meyusharin Rabbi Meir,
llm_translation: Rabbi Avahu said: Rabbi Meir differs from him, as it is stated, "And your eyelids shall look straight before you." Ramei bar Hama said to Rabbi Yirmeya from Difti: What is meant by "And your eyelids shall look straight before you"? He said to him: These are words of Torah, as it is written about them, "Do you set your eyes upon it, and it is gone." And even so, they are considered upright in the view of Rabbi Meir.

hebrew_text: רַב חִסְדָּא אַשְׁכְּחֵיהּ לְרַב חֲנַנְאֵל דַּהֲוָה כָּתֵב סְפָרִים שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב, אֲמַר לֵיהּ: רְאוּיָה כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ לִיכָּתֵב עַל פִּיךְ, אֶלָּא כָּךְ אָמְרוּ חֲכָמִים: אָסוּר לִכְתּוֹב אוֹת אַחַת שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב. מִדְּקָאָמַר: כׇּל הַתּוֹרָה כּוּלָּהּ רְאוּיָה שֶׁתִּיכָּתֵב עַל פִּיךְ, מִכְּלָל דִּמְיוּשָּׁרִין הֵן אֶצְלוֹ, וְהָא רַבִּי מֵאִיר כָּתַב? שְׁעַת הַדְּחָק שָׁאנֵי.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda found Rav Ḥananel writing scrolls, not from a written text, He said to him: It is fitting the entire Torah to be written by your mouth, but this is what the Sages said: It is prohibited to write a single letter not from a written text. Since said The entire Torah is fitting to be written by your mouth, by inference that were exact in his memory, But didn’t Rabbi Meir wrote A time of exigent circumstances is different;
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda found Rav Ḥananel who was writing books not according to the script, he said to him: It is fitting that the entire Torah should be written according to your mouth, rather the Sages said: It is forbidden to write even one letter not according to the script. From where do we derive this? From what is stated: "The entire Torah is fitting to be written according to your mouth," implying that they are all upright with him. But didn't Rabbi Meir write? In a time of pressing need, it is different.

hebrew_text: אַבָּיֵי שְׁרָא לִדְבֵי בַּר חָבוּ לְמִיכְתַּב תְּפִלִּין וּמְזוּזוֹת שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב. כְּמַאן? כִּי הַאי תַּנָּא, דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבֵּינוּ: תְּפִלִּין וּמְזוּזוֹת נִכְתָּבוֹת שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב, וְאֵין צְרִיכוֹת שִׂרְטוּט.
human_translation: Abaye permitted the house of ben Ḥavu to write phylacteries and mezuzot not from a text. In accordance with whose In accordance with the following tanna , as it is taught Rabbi Yirmeya said in the name of our master, Phylacteries and mezuzot may be written not from a written text, and they do not require scoring,
llm_translation: Abaye sent to the house of Bar Chavu regarding phylacteries and mezuzot that are not from the written text. According to whom? Like this Tanna, as it was taught: Rabbi Yirmeya says in the name of our teacher: Phylacteries and mezuzot are written not from the written text, and they do not require marking.

hebrew_text: וְהִלְכְתָא: תְּפִלִּין אֵין צְרִיכִין שִׂרְטוּט, מְזוּזוֹת צְרִיכִין שִׂרְטוּט. אִידֵּי וְאִידֵּי נִכְתָּבוֹת שֶׁלֹּא מִן הַכְּתָב. מַאי טַעְמָא — מִיגְרָס גְּרִיסִין.
human_translation: And the halakha is Phylacteries do not require scoring, mezuzot require scoring. both these and those, written not from a written text. What is the reason These are well known
llm_translation: The Halakha: Tefillin do not require sirtut, mezuzot require sirtut. Both are written without the original text. What is the reason? - Because of the verse "grasping handfuls."

hebrew_text: הָיְתָה כְּתוּבָה בְּסַם כּוּ׳. סַם — סַמָּא. סִקְרָא, אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה: סְקַרְתָּא שְׁמַהּ. קוֹמוֹס — קוֹמָא.
human_translation: was written with sam Sam samma . sikra , Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Its name sikreta , Komos koma ,
llm_translation: It was written in the Sam Kuf. Sam - Sama. Sikra, said Rabba bar bar Hana: its name is Sekarta. Komos - Koma.

hebrew_text: קַנְקַנְתּוֹם — חַרְתָּא דְאוּשְׁכָּפֵי. דִּיפְתְּרָא — דִּמְלִיחַ וּקְמִיחַ וְלָא עֲפִיץ. נְיָיר — מְחָקָא.
human_translation: Kankantom ḥarta de’ushkafei , Diftera that was processed with salt and flour, but not with gallnuts. Neyar maḥaka ,
llm_translation: "Kankantom - charta de'ushkafey. Diftrah - dimlih and k'mih and lo afitz. Niyar - mehaka."

hebrew_text: עַד שֶׁתְּהֵא כְּתוּבָה אַשּׁוּרִית, דִּכְתִיב: ״כִּכְתָבָם וְכִזְמַנָּם״.
human_translation: unless is written in Ashurit . As it is written “According to their writing and according to their time”
llm_translation: Until it is written in Assyrian, as it is written: "according to their writing and according to their language."

hebrew_text: ״עַל הַסֵּפֶר וּבִדְיוֹ וְכוּ׳״. מְנָלַן? אַתְיָא ״כְּתִיבָה״ ״כְּתִיבָה״. כְּתִיב הָכָא: ״וַתִּכְתֹּב אֶסְתֵּר הַמַּלְכָּה״, וּכְתִיב הָתָם: ״וַיֹּאמֶר לָהֶם בָּרוּךְ מִפִּיו יִקְרָא אֵלַי אֵת כׇּל הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה וַאֲנִי כּוֹתֵב עַל הַסֵּפֶר בַּדְּיוֹ״.
human_translation: “upon parchment and with ink.” From where do we derived writing writing. It is written here “Then Esther the queen, wrote and it is written there: “Then Baruch answered them: He pronounced all these words to me with his mouth, and I wrote them with ink on the parchment”
llm_translation: "On the scroll and with ink, etc." From where do we derive this? It is taught: "writing, writing." It is written here: "And Esther the queen wrote," and it is written there: "And He said to them, 'Blessed be He who calls to me from His mouth all these words, and I write on the scroll with ink.'"

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ בֶּן עִיר שֶׁהָלַךְ לִכְרַךְ וּבֶן כְּרַךְ שֶׁהָלַךְ לְעִיר, אִם עָתִיד לַחְזוֹר לִמְקוֹמוֹ — קוֹרֵא כִּמְקוֹמוֹ, וְאִם לָאו — קוֹרֵא עִמָּהֶן.
human_translation: a resident of an town who went to a walled city, a resident of a walled city who went to an town If he is destined to return to his place, he reads according to his place, and if not, he reads with them,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If a person from the city went to the village, and a person from the village went to the city, if they are destined to return to their original place - one reads the Megillah in his original place. But if not, one reads with them.

hebrew_text: וּמֵהֵיכָן קוֹרֵא אָדָם אֶת הַמְּגִילָּה וְיוֹצֵא בָּהּ יְדֵי חוֹבָה? רַבִּי מֵאִיר אוֹמֵר: כּוּלָּהּ. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מֵ״אִישׁ יְהוּדִי״. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: מֵ״אַחַר הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה״.
human_translation: from where must a person read the Megilla in order to fulfill his obligation? Rabbi Meir says: all of it. Rabbi Yehuda says: from a certain Jew” Rabbi Yosei says: From “After these things”
llm_translation: From where does a person read the Megillah and fulfill his obligation? Rabbi Meir says: in its entirety. Rabbi Yehuda says: from "a Jewish man." Rabbi Yosei says: from "after these things."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רָבָא: לֹא שָׁנוּ אֶלָּא שֶׁעָתִיד לַחְזוֹר בְּלֵילֵי אַרְבָּעָה עָשָׂר, אֲבָל אֵין עָתִיד לַחְזוֹר בְּלֵילֵי אַרְבָּעָה עָשָׂר — קוֹרֵא עִמָּהֶן. אָמַר רָבָא: מְנָא אָמֵינָא לַהּ? דִּכְתִיב: ״עַל כֵּן הַיְּהוּדִים הַפְּרָזִים הַיּוֹשְׁבִים בְּעָרֵי הַפְּרָזוֹת״. מִכְּדֵי כְּתִיב: ״הַיְּהוּדִים הַפְּרָזִים״, לְמָה לִי לְמִיכְתַּב ״הַיּוֹשְׁבִים בְּעָרֵי הַפְּרָזוֹת״? הָא קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן, דְּפָרוּז בֶּן יוֹמוֹ נִקְרָא פָּרוּז.
human_translation: Rava said: They taught only one who is destined to return on the night of the fourteenth But if he is not destined to return on the night of the fourteenth, although he reads with Rava said: From where do I say this? As it is written: “Therefore the Jews of unwalled towns, who dwell in the unwalled towns, Since it is written: “The Jews of unwalled towns,” why do I to write “who dwell in the unwalled towns”? teach us this: That one who is in an unwalled town for the day is called one who in an unwalled town.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Gemara, Rava said: They only taught this law for the night of the fourteenth of Nisan that is destined to return, but for the night of the fourteenth of Nisan that is not destined to return - one may read with them. Rava said: From where do I say this? As it is written: 'Therefore the Jews of the villages, that dwell in the unwalled towns.' Since it is written 'the Jews of the villages,' why do I need it to be written 'that dwell in the unwalled towns'? It teaches us that Paruz, who is one day old, is called Paruz." English translation:

hebrew_text: אַשְׁכְּחַן פָּרוּז, מוּקָּף מְנָא לַן? סְבָרָא הוּא: מִדְּפָרוּז בֶּן יוֹמוֹ קָרוּי פָּרוּז, מוּקָּף בֶּן יוֹמוֹ קָרוּי מוּקָּף.
human_translation: We have found an unwalled town. from where do we a walled city It is logical reasoning: Since one who is in an unwalled town for the day is called someone from an unwalled town, one who is in a walled city for a day is called someone from a walled city.
llm_translation: We find a Parutz, how do we establish for ourselves a Mukaf? It is a reasoning: from a Parutz whose son is one day old, he is called Parutz, from a Mukaf whose son is one day old, he is called Mukaf.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רָבָא: בֶּן כְּפָר שֶׁהָלַךְ לְעִיר — בֵּין כָּךְ וּבֵין כָּךְ קוֹרֵא עִמָּהֶן. מַאי טַעְמָא? הַאי כִּבְנֵי הָעִיר בָּעֵי לְמִקְרֵי, וְרַבָּנַן הוּא דַּאֲקִילּוּ עַל הַכְּפָרִים כְּדֵי שֶׁיְּסַפְּקוּ מַיִם וּמָזוֹן לַאֲחֵיהֶם שֶׁבַּכְּרַכִּין. הָנֵי מִילֵּי — כִּי אִיתֵיהּ בְּדוּכְתֵּיהּ, אֲבָל כִּי אִיתֵיהּ בְּעִיר — כִּבְנֵי עִיר בָּעֵי לְמִקְרֵי.
human_translation: And Rava said Someone from a village, where who went to a town, reads with in all circumstances, What is the reason This should read as the residents of the towns, but the Sages showed leniency toward the villages so that they supply water and food to their brethren in the cities This, applies when is in his place, but when he is in a town, he is required to read like the residents of the town,
llm_translation: And Rava said: If a resident of a village goes to the city, he may read with them, both here and there. What is the reason? Because the people of the city need to be called upon for public readings, and the Rabbis made it easier for the villagers so that they could provide water and sustenance for their brothers in the villages. Those words – when he is in his village, but when he is in the city, the people of the city need to be called upon for public readings.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: בֶּן כְּרַךְ שֶׁהָלַךְ לְעִיר — בֵּין כָּךְ וּבֵין כָּךְ קוֹרֵא כִּמְקוֹמוֹ. בֶּן כְּרַךְ סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ?! בְּאִם עָתִיד לַחְזוֹר תַּלְיָא מִילְּתָא, אֶלָּא לָאו, בֶּן כְּפָר.
human_translation: Abaye raised an objection to A resident of a walled city who went to town, in all circumstances, reads according to his place. Can it enter your mind that the resident of a walled city the matter depend on whether he will be returning Rather, is it not A resident of a village
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him: Abaye raised an objection: A son of a village who went to the city - whether this way or that way, he reads in his original place. A son of a village, is your mind at ease?! If he is likely to return, the matter is dependent, but if not, he is considered a son of a village.

hebrew_text: וְלָאו תָּרוֹצֵי מְתָרְצַתְּ? תְּנִי: קוֹרֵא עִמָּהֶן.
human_translation: But did you not emend teach: He reads with
llm_translation: "And is it not that they are running to be reconciled? Teach: One reads with them."

hebrew_text: מֵהֵיכָן קוֹרֵא אָדָם אֶת הַמְּגִילָּה וְכוּ׳. תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יוֹחַאי אוֹמֵר: מִ״בַּלַּיְלָה הַהוּא״.
human_translation: from where must a person read the Megilla It is taught Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai says: “On that night”
llm_translation: From where does a person read the Megillah, etc.? It was taught: Rabbi Shimon ben Yochai says: "From the fourteenth night of that month."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, וְכוּלָּן מִקְרָא אֶחָד דָּרְשׁוּ: ״וַתִּכְתֹּב אֶסְתֵּר הַמַּלְכָּה וּמׇרְדֳּכַי הַיְּהוּדִי אֶת כׇּל תּוֹקֶף״, מַאן דְּאָמַר כּוּלָּהּ — תּוֹקְפּוֹ שֶׁל אֲחַשְׁוֵרוֹשׁ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And all of were expounding the same verse. “Then Esther the queen, and Mordecai the Jew, wrote about all the acts of power The one who said in its entirety the power of Ahasuerus,
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Yochanan, and all of them interpreted one verse: "And Esther the queen and Mordecai the Jew wrote all the power," whoever said all of it - the power of Achashverosh.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵ״אִישׁ יְהוּדִי״ — תּוֹקְפּוֹ שֶׁל מָרְדֳּכַי, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵ״אַחַר הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה״ — תּוֹקְפּוֹ שֶׁל הָמָן, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מִ״בַּלַּיְלָה הַהוּא״ — תּוֹקְפּוֹ שֶׁל נֵס.
human_translation: And the one who said from “There was a certain Jew” the power of Mordecai. And the one who said from “After these things” the power of Haman. And the one who said from “On that night” the power of the miracle,
llm_translation: The one who says "from a Jewish man" - his strength is like Mordecai's, and the one who says "after these things" - his strength is like Haman's, and the one who says "on that night" - his strength is like a miracle.

hebrew_text: רַב הוּנָא אָמַר, מֵהָכָא: ״וּמָה רָאוּ עַל כָּכָה וּמָה הִגִּיעַ אֲלֵיהֶם״,
human_translation: Rav Huna said: from here: and of that which they saw concerning this matter, and that which had befallen them,
llm_translation: Rav Huna said, from here: "And what they saw on such and what reached them."

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר כּוּלָּהּ: ״מָה רָאָה״ — אֲחַשְׁוֵרוֹשׁ שֶׁנִּשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בְּכֵלִים שֶׁל בֵּית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ, ״עַל כָּכָה״ — מִשּׁוּם דְּחַשֵּׁיב שִׁבְעִים שְׁנִין וְלָא אִיפְּרוּק, ״וּמָה הִגִּיעַ אֲלֵיהֶם״ — דִּקְטַל וַשְׁתִּי.
human_translation: The one who said in its entirety Ahasuerus saw, in that he used the vessels of the Temple. “Concerning this matter” because he had calculated seventy years and were not redeemed, “And that which had befallen them” that he had killed Vashti.
llm_translation: The one who says: "What did he see" - Ahasuerus who made use of the vessels of the Temple, "on this account" - because he considered seventy years and did not separate, "and what has come to them" - he killed and drank.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵ״אִישׁ יְהוּדִי״: ״מָה רָאָה״ — מָרְדְּכַי דְּאִיקַּנִּי בְּהָמָן, ״עַל כָּכָה״ — דְּשַׁוִּי נַפְשֵׁיהּ עֲבוֹדָה זָרָה, ״וּמָה הִגִּיעַ אֲלֵיהֶם״ — דְּאִתְרְחִישׁ נִיסָּא.
human_translation: And the one who said from “There was a certain Jew” That which Mordecai “saw” in that he acted zealously concerning Haman. “Concerning this matter” because Haman had made himself idol worship. “And that which had befallen them” that a miracle took place.
llm_translation: The one who says "from a Jewish man": "what did he see" - Mordecai who rebuked Haman, "on this" - he risked his life for foreign worship, "and what has come to them" - a miracle occurred.

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵ״אַחַר הַדְּבָרִים הָאֵלֶּה״: ״מָה רָאָה״ — הָמָן שֶׁנִּתְקַנֵּא בְּכׇל הַיְּהוּדִים, ״עַל כָּכָה״ — מִשּׁוּם דְּמָרְדְּכַי ״לֹא יִכְרַע וְלֹא יִשְׁתַּחֲוֶה״, ״וּמָה הִגִּיעַ אֲלֵיהֶם״ — ״וְתָלוּ אוֹתוֹ וְאֶת בָּנָיו עַל הָעֵץ״.
human_translation: And the one who said from “After these things” That which Haman “saw” in that he became incensed with all the Jews. “Concerning this matter” because “Mordecai did not bow down, nor prostrate himself before him” “And that which had befallen them” “he and his sons were hanged on the gallows”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And one who says 'from after these things': 'What did he see' — Haman who was jealous of all the Jews, 'on this account' — because of Mordecai, 'he will not bow and he will not prostrate himself', 'and what has come to them' — 'and hang him and his sons on the gallows'." English translation:

hebrew_text: וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מִ״בַּלַּיְלָה הַהוּא״: ״מָה רָאָה״ — אֲחַשְׁוֵרוֹשׁ לְהָבִיא אֶת סֵפֶר הַזִּכְרוֹנוֹת, ״עַל כָּכָה״ — דְּזַמֵּינְתֵּיהּ אֶסְתֵּר לְהָמָן בַּהֲדֵיהּ, ״וּמָה הִגִּיעַ אֲלֵיהֶם״ — דְּאִתְרְחִישׁ נִיסָּא.
human_translation: And the one who said from “On that night” That which Ahasuerus “saw” to bring the book of chronicles “Concerning this matter” because Esther had invited Haman with him “And that which had befallen them” that a miracle took place.
llm_translation: The one who says "on that night": "What did he see" - Ahasuerus to bring the Book of Records, "on such" - that Esther invited Haman to her banquet, "and what happened to them" - that a miracle occurred.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חֶלְבּוֹ אָמַר רַב חָמָא בַּר גּוּרְיָא אָמַר רַב: הֲלָכָה כְּדִבְרֵי הָאוֹמֵר כּוּלָּהּ. וַאֲפִילּוּ לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מֵ״אִישׁ יְהוּדִי״ — צְרִיכָה שֶׁתְּהֵא כְּתוּבָה כּוּלָּהּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥelbo said Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said Rav said: The halakha is in accordance with the statement of the one who says in its entirety. And even according to the one who said “There was a certain Jew” must be written in its entirety.
llm_translation: Rabbi Helbo said in the name of Rav Ḥama son of Gurya who said in the name of Rav: The halakha is in accordance with the words of the one who says "in its entirety." And even according to the one who says "from a Jewish man," it is necessary that it be written in its entirety.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חֶלְבּוֹ אָמַר רַב חָמָא בַּר גּוּרְיָא אָמַר רַב: מְגִילָּה נִקְרֵאת ״סֵפֶר״, וְנִקְרֵאת ״אִגֶּרֶת״. נִקְרֵאת ״סֵפֶר״ — שֶׁאִם תְּפָרָהּ בְּחוּטֵי פִשְׁתָּן פְּסוּלָה. וְנִקְרֵאת ״אִגֶּרֶת״ — שֶׁאִם הֵטִיל בָּהּ שְׁלֹשָׁה חוּטֵי גִידִין כְּשֵׁרָה. אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן: וּבִלְבַד שֶׁיְּהוּ מְשׁוּלָּשִׁין.
human_translation: And Rabbi Ḥelbo said Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said Rav said: Megilla is referred to as a “book” and it is referred to as a “letter” It is called a book, that if one sewed with flax threads is unfit, And it is called a letter that if one stitched with three threads of sinew, is fit Rav Naḥman said: This is provided that made in three parts.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Helbo said in the name of Rav Ḥama son of Guria who said in the name of Rav: A Megillah is called a "sefer" and is also called an "iggeret." It is called a "sefer" - if one sews it with linen threads, it is invalid. And it is called an "iggeret" - if one inserts three sinew threads into it, it is valid. Rav Naḥman said: And they must be braided.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: הַקּוֹרֵא בִּמְגִילָּה הַכְּתוּבָה בֵּין הַכְּתוּבִים — לֹא יָצָא. אָמַר רָבָא: לָא אֲמַרַן אֶלָּא דְּלָא מְחַסְּרָא וּמְיַיתְּרָא פּוּרְתָּא, אֲבָל מְחַסְּרָא וּמְיַיתְּרָא פּוּרְתָּא — לֵית לַן בַּהּ.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said that Shmuel said: If one reads from a Megilla that was written together with the Writings he has not fulfilled Rava said: We said only is not a little shorter or longer But if it is a little shorter or longer we have no with it,
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: One who reads from a written Megillah among the Writings - has not fulfilled his obligation. Rava said: We only said this when it is lacking or has an excess letter, but if it lacks or has an excess letter - we do not have a problem with it.

hebrew_text: לֵוִי בַּר שְׁמוּאֵל הֲוָה קָא קָרֵי קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַב יְהוּדָה בִּמְגִילָּה
human_translation: Levi bar Shmuel was reading before Rav Yehuda from a Megilla
llm_translation: Levi bar Shmuel was reading before Rav Yehudah in Megillah.

hebrew_text: הַכְּתוּבָה בֵּין הַכְּתוּבִים. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הֲרֵי אָמְרוּ, הַקּוֹרֵא בִּמְגִילָּה הַכְּתוּבָה בֵּין הַכְּתוּבִים — לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: that was written together with the Writings. said to him: have said: If one reads from a Megilla that was written together with the Writings he has not fulfilled
llm_translation: The written text among the written texts. He said to him: They have already said, one who reads in a scroll that is written among the written texts - he has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: הַקּוֹרֵא בִּמְגִילָּה הַכְּתוּבָה בֵּין הַכְּתוּבִים — לֹא יָצָא. וּמָחוּ לַהּ אַמּוֹחָא: בְּצִבּוּר שָׁנוּ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: If one reads from a Megilla that was written together with the Writings he has not fulfilled But they hit on its head, They taught to a congregation.
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said Rabbi Yochanan: One who reads the written Megillah among the Writings - has not fulfilled his obligation. And they taught it in the West: In a congregation they established.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שִׁיּוּר הַתֶּפֶר — הֲלָכָה לְמֹשֶׁה מִסִּינַי. וּמָחוּ לַהּ אַמּוֹחָא: וְלֹא אָמְרוּ אֶלָּא כְּדֵי שֶׁלֹּא יִקָּרַע.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: leaving stitches, is a halakha to Moses from Sinai, But they hit on its head, they said only so that it not rip.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: The remnant of the dish - a halacha from Moses at Sinai. And they taught it in the academy: And they only said this in order that it not tear.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אִלְמָלֵי נִשְׁתַּיֵּיר בִּמְעָרָה שֶׁעָמַד בָּהּ מֹשֶׁה וְאֵלִיָּהוּ כִּמְלֹא נֶקֶב מַחַט סִדְקִית, לֹא הָיוּ יְכוֹלִין לַעֲמוֹד מִפְּנֵי הָאוֹרָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי לֹא יִרְאַנִי הָאָדָם וָחָי״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Had there been left a crack the size of small sewing needle in the cave in which Moses and Elijah stood they would not have been able to endure due to the light as it is stated: “For no man shall see Me and live”
llm_translation: And Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: If Moses and Elijah had remained in the cave in which Moses stood, even if it were filled with a needle of righteousness, they would not have been able to stand because of the radiance, as it is said: "For man shall not see Me and live."

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״וַעֲלֵיהֶם כְּכׇל הַדְּבָרִים אֲשֶׁר דִּבֶּר ה׳ עִמָּכֶם בָּהָר״ — מְלַמֵּד שֶׁהֶרְאָהוּ הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא לְמֹשֶׁה דִּקְדּוּקֵי תוֹרָה וְדִקְִדּוּקֵי סוֹפְרִים וּמַה שֶּׁהַסּוֹפְרִים עֲתִידִין לְחַדֵּשׁ, וּמַאי נִיהוּ? מִקְרָא מְגִילָּה.
human_translation: And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is which is written: and on them was written according to all the words which the Lord spoke with you in the mountain” This teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, showed Moses the inferences the Torah; and the inferences of the Scribes, and all that the Scribes were destined to introduce And what is it The reading of the Megilla.
llm_translation: And Rabbi Chiya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: What is the meaning of what is written: "And upon them, like all the words that the Lord spoke with you on the mountain" - this teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, showed Moses the precision of Torah and the precision of the scribes, and what the scribes are destined to innovate. And what is it? The reading of the Megillah.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הַכֹּל כְּשֵׁרִין לִקְרוֹת אֶת הַמְּגִילָּה, חוּץ מֵחֵרֵשׁ שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר בְּקָטָן.
human_translation: Everyone is fit to read the Megilla, except for a deaf person, an imbecile, and a minor. Rabbi Yehuda says that a minor is fit
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Everyone is fit to read the Megillah, except for a deaf-mute, a fool, and a minor. Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאן תְּנָא חֵרֵשׁ דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא? אָמַר רַב מַתְנָה: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא, דִּתְנַן: הַקּוֹרֵא אֶת שְׁמַע וְלֹא הִשְׁמִיעַ לְאׇזְנוֹ — יָצָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: Who is the tanna taught a deaf person, even after the fact, no, Rav Mattana said: It is Rabbi Yosei, as we learned If one recites the Shema but does not make it audible to his ears, he has fulfilled Rabbi Yosei said: He has not fulfilled
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara: Maan tana cheresh di'avad namei la? Amar Rav Matna: Rabbi Yosei hi, ditnan: HaKorei et Shema ve'lo hishmia le'ozno - yatza, Rabbi Yosei omer: Lo yatza. English translation: Gemara: Who is the Tanna that a deaf person fulfills his obligation? Rav Matna said: It is Rabbi Yosei, as we learned: One who reads the Shema but does not hear it with his ear - he has fulfilled his obligation. Rabbi Yosei says: He has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: וּמִמַּאי דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי הִיא וְדִיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא? דִּלְמָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וּלְכַתְּחִלָּה הוּא דְּלָא, הָא דִּיעֲבַד — שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי?
human_translation: But from where Rabbi Yosei, even after the fact, no, Perhaps Rabbi Yehuda, and may not ab initio , but after the fact is valid.
llm_translation: And from what is the source of Rabbi Yosei saying it, and it is done in practice not? Perhaps it is the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, and initially it is not so, but in practice — it is fitting, is it not?

hebrew_text: לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דְּקָתָנֵי חֵרֵשׁ דּוּמְיָא דְּשׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן: מָה שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן — דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא, אַף חֵרֵשׁ — דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא.
human_translation: This should not enter your mind, as teaches a deaf person is similar to an imbecile or a minor. just as an imbecile and a minor not even after the fact, so too, even after the fact, no, a deaf person
llm_translation: Your request is to translate the following Talmudic text into English word-for-word, maintaining the original style and format of Talmudic discourse. Here is the translation: Talmudic text: "לָא סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ, דְּקָתָנֵי חֵרֵשׁ דּוּמְיָא דְּשׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן: מָה שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן — דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא, אַף חֵרֵשׁ — דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא." English translation: "It is not as you think, for it was taught: A deaf-mute is similar to a fool and a minor. Just as a fool and a minor—what they do is not effective, so too a deaf-mute—what they do is not effective."

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא הָא כִּדְאִיתָא וְהָא כִּדְאִיתָא! מִדְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר בְּקָטָן — מִכְּלָל דְּרֵישָׁא לָאו רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא.
human_translation: But perhaps this as it is, and that as it is. from that the latter clause teaches: Rabbi Yehuda says that a minor is fit, it may be inferred that the first clause was not Rabbi Yehuda.
llm_translation: And perhaps this one is as that one, and that one is as this one! Since it teaches in the latter part: Rabbi Yehuda permits with a minor — from the general principle of the beginning, is it not Rabbi Yehuda.

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא כּוּלַּהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא! מִי דָּמֵי? רֵישָׁא לִפְסוּלָה, וְסֵיפָא לִכְשֵׁירָה.
human_translation: But perhaps in its entirety was Rabbi Yehuda Are comparable, The first clause to disqualify whereas the latter clause to declare fit.
llm_translation: Perhaps it is all Rabbi Yehuda! Who is similar? The beginning is for disqualification, and the end is for qualification.

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא כּוּלַּהּ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, וּתְרֵי גַוְונֵי קָטָן קָתָנֵי לַהּ, וְחַסּוֹרֵי מִיחַסְּרָא וְהָכִי קָתָנֵי: הַכֹּל כְּשֵׁרִין לִקְרוֹת אֶת הַמְּגִילָּה חוּץ מֵחֵרֵשׁ שׁוֹטֶה וְקָטָן, בַּמֶּה דְּבָרִים אֲמוּרִים — בְּקָטָן שֶׁלֹּא הִגִּיעַ לְחִינּוּךְ, אֲבָל בְּקָטָן שֶׁהִגִּיעַ לְחִינּוּךְ — אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה. שֶׁרַבִּי יְהוּדָה מַכְשִׁיר בְּקָטָן.
human_translation: But perhaps in its entirety Rabbi Yehuda And it is teaching two types of minors, and is incomplete, and is teaching the following: Everyone is fit to read the Megilla except for a deaf person, an imbecile, and a minor. In what is this statement said? with regard to a minor who has not reached training But a minor who has reached training even ab initio , as Rabbi Yehuda says that a minor is fit
llm_translation: And perhaps it is all Rabbi Yehuda, and two categories of small are taught to it, and lacking from lacking, and thus it is taught: All are fit to read the Megillah except for a deaf-mute, a fool, and a minor. In what case are these matters said? In the case of a minor who has not reached the age of education, but in the case of a minor who has reached the age of education — even initially. For Rabbi Yehuda permits with a minor.

hebrew_text: בְּמַאי אוֹקֵימְתָּא — כְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה, וְדִיעֲבַד?
human_translation: In what did you establish in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, after the fact
llm_translation: In what is it established? - Like Rabbi Yehuda, and it is established.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הָא דְּתָנֵי (רַבִּי) יְהוּדָה בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן פַּזִּי: חֵרֵשׁ הַמְדַבֵּר וְאֵינוֹ שׁוֹמֵעַ תּוֹרֵם לְכַתְּחִלָּה, מַנִּי? אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — דִּיעֲבַד אִין לְכַתְּחִלָּה לָא, אִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי — דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא.
human_translation: But that which Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, taught A deaf person who can speak but cannot hear may set aside teruma ab initio , whose If Rabbi Yehuda, after the fact, yes, not ab initio . And if Rabbi Yosei, even after the fact, no,
llm_translation: Rather, this that Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, teaches: A deaf person who speaks but does not hear, is he considered a valid agent to effect an acquisition initially? Is it according to Rabbi Yehuda — that retroactively there is no acquisition, or according to Rabbi Yosei — that retroactively there is an acquisition.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא מַאי — רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וַאֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה? אֶלָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: לֹא יְבָרֵךְ אָדָם בִּרְכַּת הַמָּזוֹן בְּלִבּוֹ, וְאִם בֵּירַךְ יָצָא, מַנִּי? לָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה וְלָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי! אִי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה — אֲפִילּוּ לְכַתְּחִלָּה, אִי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי — אֲפִילּוּ דִּיעֲבַד נָמֵי לָא!
human_translation: Rather, what Rabbi Yehuda and even ab initio , But whose is that which is taught A person should not recite the Grace after Meals in his heart, but if he recited he has fulfilled neither Rabbi Yehuda nor Rabbi Yosei. if Rabbi Yehuda, even ab initio , if Rabbi Yosei, even after the fact, no,
llm_translation: And rather what? — Rabbi Yehuda and even initially? Rather this that it was taught: A person should not bless the grace after meals in his heart, and if he did bless, he has fulfilled his obligation. Who is the authority?
